alphabetical letter h *
hu: the vowel of this pron. is sometimes, in a case of pause, transferred to the preceding letter: and this is always done in modern Arabic. ― -b2- ho subjoined in hun~aho, and the like: see A^aboyaDu. ― -b3- The haA, termed tanobiyhN, is said by some to be used as an inceptive, without any meaning but inception. (See *A.) See kalimapu tanobiyhK in art. nbh: and see an ex. voce taA. When followed by a pronoun, as hw, &c., it is best rendered Lo. ― -b4- h of pausation: see remarks on a verse cited voce HiynN. ― -b5- bihaA, in HaTaA^a bihaA, and many phrases syn. therewith, is app. for biA@sotihi. See HaTaA^a.

haA='a *
and haA='i: see art. hwA^.

Q. Q. 3 Aihobay~axa *
; (K;) and Aihobay~axato, aor. tahobay~ixu; inf. n. A_ihobiy~aAxN; (TA;) He, (K,) and she, (TA,) walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (K, TA.)

habay~axN *
, of the measure faEay~alN, (S,) A boy, or young man: and habay~axapN a girl, or damsel: both in the dial. of Himyer. (L.) ― -b2- Also, the former, A soft boy, or young man: (K:) or the former and latter, respectively, a soft, thin-skinned, and plump, boy or young man, (S,) and girl or damsel: (S, K:) or a plump and goodly young man, and woman: (L:) or the latter, a tall and great woman: (JK:) [and hence, app., applied as an epithet, in the sense of long and large, to a woman's train, in the following verse, quoted by Az,]
jar~ato Ealayohi Alr~iyHu *ayolFA A^anobaxaA
jar~a AlEaruwsi *ayolahaA A@lohabay~axaA
(L.) [The wind dragged over it a train of dusky colour, and abounding with dust, like as the bride drags her long and large train.] ― -b3- Also, the latter, A damsel suckling, or that suckles. (M, K.) ― -b4- Also, the former, A stupid, and flabby, or flaccid, man. (K.) ― -b5- Also, a man in whom is no good. (K.) ― -b6- Also, A great valley. (K) ― -b7- And A large river. (K.)

hubaEN *
, applied to a young camel: a young camel brought forth in the end of the breedingtime. (K, voce rubaEN, q. v.) See bulaEN.

1 habilato *
, inf. n. habalN: see Eamila.

8 Aihotabala *
: see 5 in art. Hfw. ― -b2- I. q. taHay~ana. (TA.)

hayobaliY~N *
A Christian monk: see A^abiylN.

mahobilN *
The place of gestation: see a verse cited voce maHobalN.

1 habAa Alr~amaAdu *
, (JK, TA,) aor. yahobuw, (TA,) The ashes became mixed with dust, and extinguished: (JK, TA:) and habAa Aljamoru. (M, art. rmd.)

hubapN *
: see A^ahobapN.

habowapN *
Dust rising, or spreading, in the sky like smoke. (JK.)

habaA='N *
The motes that are seen in the rays of the sun: (TA:) see an ex. voce guvaA='N.

1 htk *
He rent open. (K, S.) ― -b2- htk All~`h sitorahu God dishonour him: see sitorN.

hat~aAkN *
One who rends frequently tents and the like: see baAbN.

havaArahu *
, for A^anaArahu: see vwr.

5 tahaj~aEa *
He slept. (1001 Nights, ii. 321.)

hajoEapN *
(assumed tropical:) The setting of a star. (Sgh in TA, art. $rT.) See $araTN. ― -b2- A light sleep in the first part of the night. (S.)

hawojalN *
, of a ship or boat, is smaller than the A^anojar. (O, TA, voce maEaAbiyru.) ― -b2- See De Sacy, Chrest. Arab., ii. 359.

hajuwlN *
A fornicatress, or an adulteress: pl. hajaAy^ilu. (JK.)

1 hajamu Ealayohi *
He came upon him suddenly, or at unawares, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or came in to him without permission, (K,) or without asking permission: (Mgh:) he invaded, assaulted, assailed, attacked, attempted, or ventured upon, him or it: he pounced upon him or it.

hajomapN *
, or, accord. to Kz, haziyEN, The third of the five divisions of the night. (TA.) See xudorapN, and yaEofuwrN. ― -b2- As applied to camels, see EaAy^iDN and ziyAadapN.

superEntry.entry:
1 nakaHa fiY baniY fulAanK wahaj~ana A^awolaAdahumo *
[He married among the sons of such a one, and made their children to be base-born, or ignoble]. (TA in art. bgl.)

hujonapN *
[Meanness of race, in a horse]. (K, voce A_iEorAabN.)

hajiynN *
One whose father is free, or an Arab, and whose mother is a slave. (S, K.) ― -b2- A horse [half-blooded] got by a stallion of generous race out of a mare not of such race: (S:) or got
by an Arabian stallion out of a mare not of Arabian birth: (Msb:) or not of generous birth; a jade. (K.)

haAjinN *
A girl not arrived at puberty, or a beast not yet fit to be covered: see an ex. voce jal~a.

1 hajaAhu *
He censured, dispraised, reviled, or satirized him, (S, Msb, K,) in verse. (Msb, K) ― -b2- maA hajawotu minohu $ayoy^FA: see 1 in art. Hjw.

3 haAjaAhu *
, inf. n. muhaAjaApN, He contended with him in satirizing. See 4 in art. fHm.

A^umojuw~apN *
, Dispraise, is like A^usobuwbapN, contr. of A^umoduwHapN.

10 Aisotahodafa *
He became a hadaf, or butt. (Har, p. 65.) See ratiymapN.

hadafN *
A high or lofty building: see SadafN.

1 hadala *
He uttered a cry: see hadara, in two places.

5 tahad~ala *
It hung down; [it dangled;] said of a branch of a tree, (S, TA,) and of fruit; it hung loosely; said of the former. (TA.)

mi$ofarN A^ahodalu *
[A camel's lip] flaccid, or pendulous. (K, TA.)

1 hadama *
He threw down, or pulled down, a building; (Msb;) pulled it to pieces; demolished it; destroyed it: (K:) [the last two explanations are the most correct, as is shown by the phrase] naqaDa AlbinaA='a mino Eayori hadomi [He took to pieces the building without demolishing, or destroying]: (S, A, Msb, K, * in art. qwD:) he ruined [a building, &c.]; reduced [it] to ruin. (Ham, p. 31.)

6 tahaAdamati AlHiyTaAnu *
[The walls fell to ruin by degrees]. (S, in art. dEw.)

7 Ainohadama *
It became thrown down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, demolished, or destroyed: and it fell in ruins, or to pieces; or became a ruin. ― -b2- Ainohadama AlHaAy^iTu mino makaAnihi mino gayori hadomN [The wall fell in ruins, or to pieces, from its place, without being pulled to pieces]. (Lth, in TA, art. qyD.)

Ald~amu Ald~amu waAlhadoamu Alhadoamu *
: see damo.

hadamN *
Earth that is dug from a pit or well: see HafarN.

hidamolapN *
Food and drink: see fiToHalN.

hudonapN EalaY daxonK *
An illusory truce: see duxaAnN.

1 hadaAhu *
He directed him, or guided him, to the way; (K, * TA;) directed him aright; or caused him to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction. (K, TA.) See 8. ― -b2- hadaY AlEaruwsa He sent [or conducted] the bride (MA, KL) to her husband, (MA,) or to the house of her husband: (KL;) i. q. zaf~ahaA, (K in art. zf,) and so A^ahodaAhaA↓. (Msb in that art.) ― -b3- yahodiY meaning yuw^ad~iY: see an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN.

4 A^ahodaYa
see 1.

6 tahaAdanaA *
They (two parties who had been at war) made a truce, each with the other. (T, art. nb*.)

8 AihotadaY *
He became rightly directed; followed a right direction; (K;) went aright; as also hadaY↓. (S.) ― -b2- He guided himself. ― -b3- He went a right way: went aright. ― -b4- laA yahotadiY A_ilaY jihapK He cannot go aright: or knows not the way that he would pursue; or knows not in what direction to go: sometimes said of a drunken man. ― -b5- laA yahotadiY liA^amorihi means He does not, or cannot, find the way to accomplish, or perform, his affair. ― -b6- AihotadaY He found, (MA,) or took (KL,) the right way or road. (MA, KL.) ― -b7- daAhiyapu lAa yuhotadaY lahaA, by which daAhiyapu Algabari is expl. in the S and O, means laA yuhotadaY ll~an~ajaA='i minohaA, by which the same phrase is expl. in the JK: or it may be well rendered A calamity in relation to which one knows not the right course to pursue. ― -b8- AihotadaY also signifies He continued to be rightly directed, or to follow a right dirertion: and he sought to be rightly directed, or to follow a right direction. (TA.) ― -b9- Aihad~aY and Aihid~iY, for AihotadaY; like AiEa*~ara and AiEi*~ira, for AiEota*ara.

hadoYN *
A way, course, method, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or proceeding, or the like; (Msb, K;) as also hidoyapN↓ and hadoyapN↓: (K:) or to the second and third: and the first is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the last: (S:) and a god way, &c.: and calm, or placid, deportment; or calmness, or placidity, of deportment: (TA:) see also dalN. ― -b2- hadoYN [Conduct, mode of life; manners]. ＝ -A2- See hadiY~N.

huwa EalaY hudFY *
He is following, or he follows, a right direction. ― -b2- AlhudaY The Kur-án. (Bd, Jel in lxxii. 13, &c.)

hidoyapN *
and hadoyapN: see hadoyN.

hadiy~apN *
[n. un. of hadiY~N] A present; i. e. a thing sent to another in token of courtesy or honour: (Msb;) such as is termed TariyfN and laTafN. (JK.) ― -b2- hadoYN↓ and hadiY~N [coll. gen. ns.] What one brings as an offering to Mekkeh, (K,) or to the Kaabeh, (Beyd, v. 2,) or to the Haram, (S, Mgh,) consisting of camels (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb) or other beasts, (Lth,) namely kine or sheep or goats, (Mgh,) to be sacrificed, (TA,) and of goods or commodities: (Lth:) n. un. with p. (S, &c.) ― -b3- Also, Camels, absolutely. (TA.) ― -b4- hadiY~N also One who is entitled to respect, or honour, or protection: so in a verse cited voce AisotabaA='a. (ISk in T in art. bwA^.)

haAdK *
: see an ex. of its pl. hawaAdiY meaning Necks of horses, voce taAlK. ― -b2- haAdiyapN The fore part of the neck of a horse. (K in art. slf.) ― -b3- A^axa*a haAdiYa Alr~aHaY fajaEala yudiyruhaA [He took the handle of the mill, and begun to turn it]. (K, art. xbz.)

A^ahodaY mino duEayomiySi Alr~amoli *
More expert, &c: see art. dEmS.

AlmahodiY~u *
, meaning The directed by God to the truth, is a proper name, and the name of him of whose coming at the end of time the happy tidings have been announced. (TA.) [It is always so pronounced by the Arabs in the present day: not AlmuhodiY.]

1 ha*~a bisaloHihi *
He ejected his excrement. (TA, art. tr.)

1 ha*aY *
He talked nonsense; he raved, or talked irrationally, foolishly, or deliriously; (JK, K;) by reason of disease or some other cause. (K.) ― -b2- ha*aYbihi He talked irrationally, &c., with him. (TA.) ― -b3- And He mentioned him, or it, in his irrational, &c., talk. (TA.)

3 gaEada yuhaA*iYA^aSoHaAbahu *
[He sat talking irrationally, &c., with his companions]. (TA.) ― -b2- samiEotuhumo yatahaA*uwna [I heard them talking together irrationally, &c.] (TA.)

$araAbN haA*K *
(tropical:) [Beverage causing delirious, or irrational, talk.] (TA.)

1 har~a *
, inf. n. hir~N, He drove sheep or goats:
(IAar, in S, K, voce bir:) or he called them. (Yoo, in TA, ibid.)

hirojaAlN *
, pl. haraAjyl, A tall, long-bodied, or bulky, she-camel: (TA:) see hirojaAb.

haraAHa *
: see A^araAHa.

harAasN *
A certain thorny or prickly tree, (S, K, TA,) the thorns or prickles of which are like the Hasak, (TA,) and its fruit is like the nabiq: n. un. with p. (K, TA.) See quTobN.

hiro$af~apN *
A piece of rag with which water is dried up from the ground. (TA, art. jf.) ― -b2- See hiro$ab~apN.

hiroTaAlN *
A large long-bodied man. (Az, in TA, voce hirodab~apN.)

1 hariqo EalaY xamorika *
[Pour water upon thy wine; i. e.,] quiet thine anger. (T.) See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 875; also the same, ii. 877. ― -b2- hariqo Ean~aA mino ruwbapi All~ayoli: see ruwbapN.

4 A^ahoriqo Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyrapi *
, i. q. A^aborido, q. v. (IAar, in TA, art. fyH.) See 4 in art. rwq. ― -b2- haraAqahu and A^ahorAaqahu and haraqahu↓, aor.
haraqa
, inf. n. haroqN, He poured it out, or forth: see 4 in art. rwq. ― -b3- hariyquwA Eanokumo A^aw~ala All~ayoli, (in the K, erroneously, Ealayokumo,) Alight ye in the first of the night: (TA:) or disburden yourselves (A^anoziluwA Enkm): or relieve, or rest, yourselves; which seems to be generally meant by hryqwA Enkm.

hiraAqapN *
and A_ihoraAfapN The seminal fluid of a man: see A_iraAqapN, in art. rwq.

Q. Q. 1 harowala *
He walked quickly: (Msb:) [he went a kind of trotting pace between a walk and a run; see ramala;) harowalapN is not so quick as xababN [an amble]; (Msb;) and is between ma$oYN [a walk] and EadowN [a run]: (S, Msb, K:) it is a kind of EadowN: (S:) or quicker than EanaqN: or a quick walk. (K.)

1 harima *
He became extremely aged; (K;) old and infirm; (Msb;) decrepit; or a weak old man.

harimN *
The mind: see 6 in art. rq.

Alkur~u AlhaAruwniY~u *
: see kur~N.

div1.superEntry: hrnSn The hrnSAnp, (K,) i. e. hironiSaAnap, (TA,) or hirinoSaAnap, (so in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K,) with kesr, (K,) and the r quiescent, and with kesr to the n, (TA,) is A certain worm, (K,) accord. to IAar; said by others to be (TA) what is called the surofap [which is very variously described]. (K, TA.) See duxolulN.

superEntry.entry:
huroYN *
A granary: see niborN.

hazaw~arN *
A strong boy or young man: and a weak old man: as also Hazaw~arN: pl. hazAawirapN. (Abu-t-Teiyib, in TA, art. Hzr.)

haziyEN *
: see hajomapN.

1 hazolN *
is contr. of jid~N. (S, Mgh, K.) You say, hazala, aor.
hazila
, inf. n. hazolN; (S, Msb, K;) and hazila, aor.
hazala
, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and haAzala↓; (K;) He jested, or joked; (Msb;) or was not serious, or in earnest; (TA;) fiY kalAamihi in his speech; (Msb, TA;) and fiY AlA^amori in the affair. (TA.)

3 haAzala *
He jested, or joked. (K.) See 1.

huzAalN *
Leanness, meagreness, emaciation: contr. of fatness. (S, K.)

hazolaY *
, pl. of haziylN Lean, meagre, emaciated. (K, voce xa$abN.)

mahozuwlN *
: see two exs. in a verse cited voce EiroDN.

7 Ainohazama *
It (an army) was routed, discomfited, defeated, or put to flight. (K, &c.) See HaASa, in art. HyS; and AinoHaAza, in art. Hwz; from both of which it is distinguished.

hazomapN *
The [purring, or] sound of the throat of a cat. (TA.) ― -b2- The pit between the two collar-bones. (TA, art. trb.) ― -b3- [The pit above a horse's eye.] (K, voce waqobN.) See also xunoEubapN, and qalotapN: and see EuqomN, where it seems to mean a stricture: it generally and properly signifies a depression, or dint: or a pit, or small hollow, resembling a dint: see also gayobN.

mahozuwmu AlS~adori *
Depressed of breast, i. e., apparently, illiberal, niggardly: see HawoDN.

2 ha$~amahu *
, inf. n. taho$iymN, He broke it [much, or so crushed it]; (TA;) namely, a dry thing, and anything hollow, such as the head, and the like. (TA in art. $dx.)

5 taha$~ama *
It (a plant, or herbage,) became ha$iym, i. e. dry, and broken in pieces.

ha$iymN *
A plant that is dry, and breaks, or is broken, in pieces. (S, Msb, K.)

haA$imapN *
A wound in the head which breaks the bone: see $aj~apN.

Alkur~u AlhaA$imiY~u *
: see kur~N.

1 hDamahu * and AihotaDamahu
: see taxaw~afahu. ― -b2- haDama lahu mino maAlihi: see xaDama.

5 tahaD~ama
see 7.

7 AinohaDama *
It (a thing) melted, or dissolved, after being congealed. (JK.) ― -b2- AinohaDamati Alv~amarapu, and tahaD~amat↓, The fruit broke; or became broken, or crushed; syn. ta$ad~axato; (TA;) and became mellow, so as to be easy of digestion. See also bawoEN ― -b3- AinohaDama, said of food, (MA), It was, or became, digestible, or easy of digestion. (MA, KL.) ― -b4- AinohDaAmN of the zawor [app. Depression]. (K in art. jnf. [There coupled with duxuwlN.]) See also SaqalN.

8 A_ihotaDama
see 1. ― -b2- AihotaDama Al$~ajaza mino A^aEalAahu (K voce $aEaba) He cropped the tops of the shrubs: see $aEaba.

haDamN *
Contraction of the sides, (S, K,) and lankness of the belly, and smallness of the flank: (K:) in a horse it is a fault. (S.)

haDuwmN *
: see haADuwmN.

haADuwmN *
Any medicine [or other thing (see HaATuwmN)] that is a digestive of food; as also haDuwmN↓; (K;) i. q. jawaAri$N. (S.)

1 haTala *
It (water) poured: see its inf. n. voce sakobN.

hif~N *
Certain small fish, which are dried: see sumayokaA='u.

1 hfA *
, said of the heart, It fluttered, or palpitated; and, as Z says, was flurried by reason of grief, or of beating. (TA.) See 1, in art. fhw.

hafowapN *
A slip, lapse, fault, or fall into wrongdoing; pl. hafawaAtN. (TA.)

qarabN haqohaAqN *
: see HaqoHaAqN.

hiqowar~N *
A large, long-bodied man. (Az, in TA, voce hirodab~apN.)

AlhaqoEapu *
Three small stars [ λ, φ 1, and φ 2, of Orion,] forming the points of a triangle, in the head of AljuwozAa'u The 5th Mansion of the Moon. (El-Kazweenee.) [This is accord. to those who make nawo'N to signify the “ auroral setting: ” accord. to those who make it to signify the “ auroral rising, ” these stars compose AlhanoEapu, q. v.; and AlhafoEapu seems to consist of o 1 and o 2 of Orion.]

1 hak~a *
: see sak~a.

haAk~N *
: see faAk~N.

hak~aAkN *
: see fak~aAkN.

4 A^aholalonaA hilaAla $ahori ka*aA *
: see salaxa.

10 Aisotahal~a *
: see a verse cited at the close of the first paragraph of art. DHk. ― -b2- See also a verse cited voce A^afovaA^a. ― -b3- See musotahal~N.

halo *
may be originally halow or haloY or hal~: (Akh, in S, voce bl:) see balo. ― -b2- halo followed by A_ilaY: see the latter. ― -b3- HaY~ hala: see HY. ― -b4- hal~aA: see HaD~apN and Eano, latter part, and lawolaA, and A^al~aA.

hal~apN *
: see bal~apN.

AlhilAalu *
The new moon; or the moon when it is termed hilAal: it may be explained as meaning, generally, the moon when near the sun, or moon a little after or before the change. ― -b2- See samaA.

musotahal~u Al$~ahori *
The first night of the lunar month. (Msb.)

yawomN hil~awofN *
: see A^aHaS~u.

1 halaka *
, inf. n. halaAkN &c., (S, K, &c.,) He, or it, perished, came to nought, came to an end, passed away, was not, was no more, or became non-existent or annihilated: (KL, PS in explanation of halAakN, &c.:) or fell: or became in a bad, or corrupt, state; became corrupted, vitiated, marred, or spoiled: or went away, no one knew whither: (Mgh in explanation of halAakN:) he died. (K.) ― -b2- halakato A^aroDuhu His land had its herbage dried up by drought: see jariba.

4 A^aholakahu *
He destroyed, made an end of, or caused to perish or come to an end, made away, did away with, or brought to nought, him, or it; took away his life.

6 tahaAlaka gam~FA *
[app. He perished gradually by reason of grief.] (A, art. sws: see 1 in that art.) ― -b2- tahaAlaka Ealayohi He was vehemently eager for it. (TA.) ― -b3- tahaAlaka fiyhi He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, in it, namely in running; as also Aihotalaka↓. (TA.) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, and hastened, in it, namely an affair; as also Asthlk fyh↓. (TA.) ― -b4- tahaAlakato said of a she-camel, i. q. Ea$iqato [She vehemently desired the stallion]. (AA, TA in art. E$q.)

8 A_ihotalaka
see 6.

10 Aisotaholaka *
properly signifies He sought, or courted, destruction; like AisotamaAta: see musotamiyta: and see an ex. voce $aro$arapN. ― -b2- Aisotaholaka fiY ka*aA He (a man) distressed, troubled, or fatigued, himself in, or respecting, such a thing. (TA.) See also 6.

halakapN *
The drying up of the plants, or herbage. (AHn, TA.) See halAakN.

halAakN *
[Perdition; destruction; a state of perdition or destruction: a lost state;] death. (K.) ― -b2- halAakN and halakapN↓ are syn. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- Airotabaka fiY AinohalakaAti He stuck fast in cases of perdition: see art. rbk.

haAlikN *
Dead; or dying. (Bd, Jel in xii. 85) ― -b2- haAlikN sometimes means Subject to perish; as in the Kur, xxviii. last verse.

maholukN *
: see A^aluwkN.

maholikN *
Death: see a verse cited voce sahuwN.

maholaikapN *
A cause of perdition, or of death. (TA in art. bxl.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A place of perdition or death: and a desert: (KL:) or a [desert, or such as is termed] mafaAzap; (S, K, TA;) because persons perish therein; (Z, TA;) or because it urges [or leads] to perdition. (TA.) See jaAd~apN.

huwa musotaholikN A_ilaY ka*aA *
i. q. musotamiytN [q. v.]. (TA, art. mwt, from the A.) ― -b2- musotaholiku Alwirodi A road that destroys him who seeks water, by reason of its far extent. (O.)

halum~a *
i. q. naEaAla Come. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- It is intrans.; as in halum~a A_ilayonaA Come to us. And tran also; as in halum~a $uhadaA='a kumo Cause your witnesses to come; bring your witnesses. (Msb.) ― -b3- halum~a jar~FA At thine ease: see 1 in art. jr.

1 ham~a *
He purposed, or intended, a thing. ham~N denotes more than A_iraAdapN, and less than EazomN.
